reviewText: Before I proceed, I want to point out that my copy lists "Fuzzy Settles Down" but on the disc itself is "Wild Horse Phantom." The other three titles are on the disc as listed.Buster and Al St. John had great chemistry which is the significant factor that lifts these poverty row films to a very entertaining level. VCI did a fine job (as much as possible) in restoring these movies.
summary: Good Chemistry Between Crabbe and St. John
Title: N/A

reviewText: Buster Crabbe has always been one of my favorite actors. Unfortunately, his Westerns have suffered neglect over the years. I have several on VHS and when this DVD version appeared, I snapped it up...only to discover that the quality really sucks. The picture is dark and murky. And in several cases there were so many splices and missing frames I finally gave up. I'd give this half a star if I could. Maybe someday someone will dig out pristine copies or the negative (not likely!) and we'll get to see these gems as they were meant to be seen. Meanwhile, stay away from this turkey!
Title: N/A

reviewText: GREAT value for the money spent; Buster Crabbe must have thanked his lucky stars when Al FUZZY St. John signed on. Great comedic duo as well as good movies!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a 1946 black and white western filmed during the days when westerns had no deep meaning, filmed just for fun. It stars Buster Crabbe as the fearless man who helps people in distress. He is not a gunfighter and there is no shootout duels. He is in three fist fights - hands only, no feet nor judo - and wins them all. The pistol and rifle shooting in the film is from afar. Crabbe's sidekick is Al "Fuzzy" St. John, called "Fuzzy" or "Fuzz" in the film. He gives most of the comic parts, which take up many minutes of the film. He is a bearded elderly man who apparently lacks either upper or lower teeth, or both. He acts in a silly manner and wears a beat-up hat, baggy pants, and suspenders. He also gets into three fist fights. Loses two and comes out in a draw on the third when he wrestles the Englishman's butler, who also adds humor to the approximately one hour film.There is a gang of rustlers in the area who take their rustled cattle through unused Hidden Valley. They keep town people away by insisting that there is a ghost in Hidden Valley. An Englishman comes to town to repossess Hidden Valley, which he inherited from his father. The Englishman is dressed in caricature western cloths because his London tailor assured him that this is what people wear in the west. He also acts in a caricature English fashion. He brought his butler along who waits on him. The Butler is appalled at Fuzz's uncouth behavior and frequently tells him so, adding more humor. The Englishman is unable to fight and Crabbe saves him from the rustlers who are determined to get rid of him so that they can resume their lucrative rustling career.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Poverty Row Pictures present "SHERIFF OF SAGE VALLEY" (2 September 1942) (54 mins/B&W;) (Fully Restored/Dolby Digitally Remastered) --- The American actor Buster Crabbe graduated from the University of Southern California and won the 400 meter freestyle in which he medaled in the 1932 Olympics, went to work for Paramount in "King of the Jungle" (1933), next role was "Tarzan the Fearless (1933), Crabbe returned to Paramount Pictures was featured in Zane Grey Westerns which were well received, then came the roles that made him a household word "Flash Gordon" and "Buck Rogers" at Universal Picture Serials (1936-1940), meanwhile PRC Studios was looking for a leading hero "Billy the Kid" and "Billy Carson" in the 1940's B-Western series and ran its course for six years, later made several televison appearances and appeared in a series "Captain Gallant and the Foreign Legion" (1955-1957)Under the production staff of:Sam Newfield  - DirectorSigmund Neufeld  - ProducerMilton M. Raison  - ScreenwriterGeorge Wallace Sayre  - ScreenwriterJohn H. Greenhalgh, Jr.  - CinematographerJohnny Lange  - Composer (Music Score)Lew Porter  - Composer (Music Score)Holbrook Todd  - EditorThe story line and plot, Billy the Kid (Buster Crabbe) and his pals Fuzzy (Al St. John) and Jeff (Dave O'Brien), on the run from the law again, travel to Sage Valley where Billy is made Sheriff --- The local outlaw gang is run by Kansas Ed Bonney (Buster Crabbe) who closely resembles Billy --- Ed captures Billy and changing clothes with him, now plans to run the town as Sheriff --- What trouble lies ahead for this exciting oater --- Some classic badmen Charles King, Kermit Maynard and John Merton give this sagebrush tale some teeth --- Another dual role for our hero Buster Crabbe comes off with perfection.the cast includes:Buster Crabbe ...  Billy the Kid / Kansas Ed BonneyAl St. John ...  Fuzzy (as Al 'Fuzzy' St. John)Dave O'Brien ...  Jeff (as Tex O'Brien)Maxine Leslie ...  Janet, Casino SingerCharles King ...  Sloane, Casino ProprieterJohn Merton ...  Nick, Kansas HenchmanKermit Maynard ...  Henchman Slim JankinsHal Price ...  Mayor Jed HarrisonJimmy Aubrey ...  Casino BartenderLynton Brent ...  HenchmanBudd Buster ...  Rancher Tim PineArt Dillard ...  RancherBert Dillard ...  Billy's Guard at ShackCurley Dresden ...  HenchmanFrank Ellis ...  RancherJack Evans ...  BarflyRay Henderson ...  HenchmanJack Kirk ...  Stage guardCarl Mathews ...  RancherMerrill McCormick ...  RancherMilburn Morante ...  BarflyAl Taylor ...  Casino CroupierDan White ...  RancherSPECIAL FEATURES:BIOS:1. Buster Crabbe (aka: Clarence Linden Crabbe II)Date of Birth: 17 February 1907 - Oakland, CaliforniaDate of Death: 23 April 1983 - Scottsdale, Arizona2. Al "Fuzzy" St. John (aka: Alfred St. John)Date of Birth: 10 September 1893 - Santa Ana, CaliforniaDate of Death: 21 January 1963 - Lyons, Georgia3. Charles KingDate of Birth: 21 February 1895 - Hillsboro, TexasDate of Death: 7 May 1957 - Hollywood, CaliforniaIf you crave action, drama and plenty of adventure check out other Buster Crabbe titles --- Ask Amazon.Com to carry the volumes as they are not available on Amazon as of yet --- you can order and pick up your copy now from VCI EntertainmentBUSTER CRABBE - RELEASED BY VCI ENTERTAINMENT:1. WESTERN DOUBLE FEATURE Vol 1: Western Cyclone & Sheriff of Sage Valley (1942)2. WESTERN DOUBLE FEATURE Vol 2: Fugitive of the Plains & Fuzzy Settles Down (1943)3. CLASSIC WESTERNS -: Fugitive of the Plains, Fuzzy Settles Down, Western Cyclone, Sheriff of Sage Valley4. TO THE LAST MAN (with Randolph Scott & Buster Crabbe)5. BUCK ROGERS (Serial)6. FLASH GORDON CONQUERS THE UNIVERSE (Serial)Hats off and thanks to Les Adams (collector/guideslines for character identification), Chuck Anderson (Webmaster: The Old Corral/B-Westerns.Com), Boyd Magers (Western Clippings), Bobby J. Copeland (author of "Trail Talk"), Rhonda Lemons (Empire Publishing Inc) and Bob Nareau (author of "The Real Bob Steele") as they have rekindled my interest once again for B-Westerns and Serials --- If you're into the memories of B-Westerns with high drama, this is the one you've been anxiously waiting for --- please stand up and take a bow Western Classics --- all my heroes have been cowboys!Total Time: 54 mins on DVD ~ Poverty Row ~ (5/27/2008)

reviewText: My father had me get these for him, and reported back to me on them. He said the quality of the video & audio was fine, but there were scenes missing from the movies that appeared as gaps in the stories. He has seen these films many times & knew which scenes were cut. Still, they were good movies but be aware that there WILL be spots that jump from scene to scene with no explanation.
Title: N/A
